FedFair: Training Fair Models In Cross-Silo Federated Learning

Lingyang Chu1, Lanjun Wang2, Yanjie Dong3, Jian Pei4, Zirui Zhou3, Yong Zhang3 1McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada.
2Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Beijing, China.
3Huawei Technologies Canada Co., Ltd., Burnaby, Canada.
4Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, Canada.
chul9@mcmaster.ca, lanjun.wang@huawei.com, yanjie.dong@huawei.com,
jpei@cs.sfu.ca, zirui.zhou@huawei.com, yong.zhang3@huawei.com.
Abstract

Building fair machine learning models becomes more and more important. As many powerful models are built by collaboration among multiple parties, each holding some sensitive data, it is natural to explore the feasibility of training fair models in cross-silo federated learning so that fairness, privacy and collaboration can be fully respected simultaneously. However, it is a very challenging task, since it is far from trivial to accurately estimate the fairness of a model without knowing the private data of the participating parties. In this paper, we first propose a federated estimation method to accurately estimate the fairness of a model without infringing the data privacy of any party. Then, we use the fairness estimation to formulate a novel problem of training fair models in cross-silo federated learning. We develop FedFair, a well-designed federated learning framework, which can successfully train a fair model with high performance without any data privacy infringement. Our extensive experiments on three real-world data sets demonstrate the excellent fair model training performance of our method.

Index Terms:
federated learning, model fairness, cross-silo

I Introduction

Fairness and collaboration are among the top priorities in machine learning and AI applications. As accurate machine learning models are deployed in more and more important applications, enhancing and ensuring fairness in machine learning models becomes critical for AI for social good [1].

At the same time, in order to build effective machine learning models for sophisticated applications, such as finance and medicare, more often than not, many parties, such as financial institutions or medical care organizations, have to collaborate and contribute their own private data. A key to successful collaborations is to fully protect the privacy of every party. However, it is a grand challenge to facilitate collaboration among parties to build fair machine learning models while preserving their data privacy.

There are many recent breakthroughs in enhancing fairness in machine learning models (see [1] for a survey and Section II-A for a brief review). There are also many efforts in cross-silo federated learning [2] to enable privacy preserving collaboration between tens or hundreds of companies and organizations in building effective machine learning models. However, only very recently there are some initiatives to develop federated learning methods for building fair machine learning models.

Can we easily extend the existing fairness enhancing methods to accommodate the need of collaboration and privacy preservation? As analyzed in Section II-A, the existing fairness enhancing methods are mainly designed with an assumption of a unified available training data set, and thus cannot easily address the need of distributed collaboration, such as cross-silo federated learning, as well as privacy preservation for participating parties.

Alternatively, can we easily extend the existing federated learning, the prominent collaboration and privacy preserving framework, to enforce fairness in model building? Unfortunately, the answer is still no. As analyzed in Section II-B, the existing federated learning methods do not consider the fairness of machine learning models at all. Moreover, in order to obtain fairness of a model as the intermediate result on the training data of each party, a straightforward design may likely infringe privacy of the parties, such as leaking the distribution information about the data of the parties. As discussed in Section II-B, even AgnostiFair [3], the only existing method claiming to combine federated learning and fairness, is pretty primitive and does not guarantee the requirement of privacy preservation.

In this paper, we tackle the novel problem of training fair models in cross-silo federated learning. We systematically model the problem and develop a comprehensive solution that theoretically guarantees both the fairness and privacy preservation requirements. Our key idea is to carefully design the fairness constraint so that it can be enforced in the whole learning process in a federated manner. In other words, the fairness constraint is implemented in a fully collaborative and privacy preserving way. Moreover, the problem of training fair models in cross-silo federated learning presents a challenging optimization problem to maximize accuracy and ensure fairness. To solve the problem we develop an elegant solution based on alternating gradient projection [4] in optimization.

We make the following contributions. First, we propose a federated estimation method to accurately estimate the fairness of a model without infringing the data privacy of any party. Second, we prove that the federated estimation method is more accurate than locally estimating the fairness of a model on individual parties, which leads to a superior fair model training performance in cross-silo federated learning. Third, by incorporating the model fairness estimation as a fairness constraint with a widely adopted federated loss function [5], we formulate our novel FedFair problem. We also develop an effective federated learning framework to tackle this problem without infringing the data privacy of any party. Last, we conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the superior fair model training performance of FedFair on three real-world datasets.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. We review related works in Section II. In Section IV, we formulate the problem. We develop the practical solutions in Section V and report systematic experimental results in Section VI. We conclude the paper in Section VIII.

II Related Works

In this section, we briefly review the related works on fairness related machine learning models.

II-A Fairness Enhancing Methods

Fairness has been recognized more and more important in machine learning and AI [1]. Correspondingly, fairness enhancing methods improve fairness in machine learning models. Please see [1] for a thorough survey. The existing methods can be categorized into three groups, namely pre-processing methods [6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12], post-processing methods [13, 14, 15, 16] and in-processing methods [17, 18, 19, 20, 21].

The pre-processing methods [6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12] enhance fairness of models by rectifying training data. The early methods [6, 7] modify the labels of some training instances that are close to the decision boundary. The recent works [8, 9, 10, 11, 12] adjust the feature representations of training data to reduce the influence of fairness-sensitive features on the model training process. Those methods collect and pre-process all training data together, and thus are not applicable to federated learning, since in federated learning the private data sets of participating parties are not allowed to be exposed to or collected by any other parties.

The post-processing methods [13, 14, 15, 16, 22] revise the prediction scores of a machine learning model to make predictions fairer than those by the original model. For example, Hardt et al. [15] flip some decisions of a classifier to make it fairer. Corbett et al. [13] and Menon et al. [16] comprehensively consider the influence of modifying prediction scores on prediction accuracy. Those methods are compatible with many trained models. However, since they are applied at a late stage in the learning process, those methods usually cannot obtain a good fairness and may sometimes sacrifice considerable accuracy of a model [19].

In-processing methods [23, 18, 17, 19, 21, 24, 20, 10, 11, 25] customize machine learning algorithms to directly train fair models. For example, Agarwal et al. [23] propose a reduction method for building fair classifiers. Based on the reduction method, Agarwal et al. [24] further propose an in-process minimax optimization formulation to enhance the fairness of regression tasks. Quadrianto et al. [21] extend logistic regression into a multi-objective loss function, which combines fair representation learning with an in-process model training algorithm. Most in-processing methods are tightly coupled with specific machine learning algorithms and need to know all training data [1]. Therefore, they are not applicable to federated learning, either, due to infringements of the data privacy of participating parties.

Our method also customizes the learning process to directly train fair models. However, it is dramatically different from the in-processing methods, since our method lets multiple parties collaborate to train fair models without infringing their data privacy.

II-B Fair Models and Federated Learning

There is a rich body of literature on federated learning. Please see [26, 2] for excellent surveys. Here, we focus on connecting fair models and federated learning.

The classical federated learning methods [5, 27, 28, 29, 26] are mostly designed to protect privacy instead of training fair models. A straight-forward extension to train fair models is to apply fairness constraints locally on each participating party. However, as discussed later in Subsection V-C, this leads to an inferior fairness performance due to the inaccurate model fairness measurements computed locally on each participating party.

The AgnosticFair method [3] attempts to train fair models that adapts well on unknown testing data by assigning a reweighing value on each training data instance in both the loss function and the fairness constraint. However, it cannot fully protect data privacy because learning the reweighing values needs strong prior knowledge on the data distribution and also requires sensitive information that leaks the data distribution of every participating party.

Mohri et al. [30] induce a weak notion of fairness for machine learning models as a side product by minimizing the maximum training loss incurred on the protected classes. However, this only mitigates the training procedure bias but cannot guarantee a good fairness of trained models [30].

The collaborative fairness methods [31, 32, 33, 30, 34, 35, 36] focus on balancing the rewards paid to the participating parties based on their contributions to the federated learning process. A typical line of works [31, 32, 33] combine incentive schemes with game theory to determine the payoff received by each party commensurate according to the contribution. Using a similar idea, Lyu et al. [35] and Sim et al. [36] achieve a better collaborative fairness performance by directly using model accuracy as the reward for the parties. Some other works [30, 34] advocate egalitarian equity in the collaboration by optimizing the performance of the party with the worst performance. The collaborative fairness task is substantially different from our study, because our task focuses on enhancing the fairness of a machine learning model, but the collaborative fairness task focuses on the fairness of the collaboration relationship among participating parties in the federated learning process.

III Preliminary: Model Fairness Measurements

Many fairness measurements have been proposed in literature [37, 38, 9, 39, 40, 15, 25]. But only a few of them are suitable for training fair models in a federated learning framework. In this section, we review existing fairness measures and discuss their applicability to training fair models in a federated manner.

Existing model fairness measurements can be categorized into two major groups. The individual fairness [37, 38] measures the fairness of a model by evaluating how likely a pair of similar instances receive similar predictions from the model. The group fairness [9, 39, 40, 15, 25] measures model fairness by evaluating how balanced the predictions of a model are on a pre-defined pair of protected groups (e.g., ‘female’ versus ‘male’). It is well recognized that individual fairness measurements are less stable than group fairness measurements [1, 41]. Thus, in this paper, we focus on group fairness measurements.

Many group fairness measurements such as disparate impact [9], demographic parity [39, 37, 40], equal odds and equal opportunities [15] are developed based on the prediction accuracy of a model. However, since the prediction accuracy of a model is a non-smooth and non-differentiable function, it is very difficult, if not impossible at all, to formulate such a fairness measurement as a fairness constraint embedded into a federated model training algorithm.

To tackle this problem, some methods [3, 42] convert prediction accuracy based measurements into smooth surrogate constraints. But the fairness performance of the trained models is limited by the approximation error between the surrogate constraints and the original fairness measurements [25].

Xu et al. [41] and Cotter et al. [43] propose a series of fairness measurements that can be smoothly integrated into a training process. However, those methods are still not applicable to our task, because they require to know some proportions of instances contained in each of the protected groups and thus infringe the data privacy of the participating parties by revealing the distributions of their private data over the protected groups.

Hashimoto et al. [44] and Baharlouei et al. [45] develop several measurements that do not consider the base prediction accuracy of a model, thus they cannot always ensure fairness, and may potentially cripple the optimization objective of a training process [37, 15].

As discussed later in Section IV-A, we formulate a novel problem of federated fair model training. Our model adopts the general fairness measurement named DGEO [25], and successfully adapts DGEO to achieve an outstanding federated fair model training performance without infringing the data privacy of any client.

IV Problem Formulation

In this section, we first review the fairness constraint based on a general fairness measurement named difference of generalized equal opportunities (DGEO) [25]. Then, we formulate the problem of federated fair model training.

IV-A The DGEO Constraint

Denote by (𝐱,s,y)𝐱𝑠𝑦(\mathbf{x},s,y) a triple of random variables drawn from an unknown distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, where 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a d𝑑d-dimensional vector of features, s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\} is the membership of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} between a pair of pre-defined protected groups (e.g., a𝑎a for “female” and b𝑏b for “male”), and y∈{1,…,C}𝑦1…𝐶y\in\{1,\ldots,C\} is the class label of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. A sample of (𝐱,s,y)𝐱𝑠𝑦(\mathbf{x},s,y) is called a data instance (instance for short).

Denote by fθ:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝜃→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{\theta}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} a model parametrized by a set of parameters θ𝜃\theta. For a loss function ℓ​(fθ​(𝐱),y)∈ℝℓsubscript𝑓𝜃𝐱𝑦ℝ\ell(f_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}),y)\in\mathbb{R}, the DGEO [25] of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} with respect to the instances contained in the protected groups {a,b}𝑎𝑏\{a,b\} and belonging to a protected class c∈{1,…,C}𝑐1…𝐶c\in\{1,\ldots,C\}.

Definition 1.

Let Ls,c​(θ)=𝔼​[ℓ​(fθ​(𝐱),y)|s,y=c]superscript𝐿𝑠𝑐𝜃𝔼delimited-[]conditionalℓsubscript𝑓𝜃𝐱𝑦𝑠𝑦𝑐L^{s,c}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}[{\ell(f_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}),y)|s,y=c}] be the expected conditional loss of a model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} on the samples in a protected group s𝑠s with a protected class label c𝑐c. The DGEO of the model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} with respect to the class c𝑐c is the absolute difference between La,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta) and Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{b,c}(\theta), that is, |La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)|superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃\left|{L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|.

A smaller DGEO means fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} commits more similar errors on each of the two protected groups of instances contained in a class c𝑐c, which further indicates fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is fairer with respect to the instances in class c𝑐c [25]. Oppositely, a larger DGEO means fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is more unfair.

Donini et al. [25] propose the notion of DGEO constraint. For a given threshold ϵ≥0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geq 0 indicating the maximum unfairness we can tolerate, a model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is said to be ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-fair if it satisfies

|La,c​(fθ)−Lb,c​(fθ)|≤ϵ.superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐subscript𝑓𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐subscript𝑓𝜃italic-ϵ\left|{L^{a,c}(f_{\theta})-L^{b,c}(f_{\theta})}\right|\leq\epsilon. (1)

IV-B Federated Fair Model Training

Now we formulate the task of training fair models in cross-silo federated learning (federated fair model training for short). Essentially, the task allows a group of parties called clients to collaborate through a cloud server to train a fair and accurate model without infringing the data privacy of any client.

Formally, denote by U1,…,UNsubscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑁U_{1},\ldots,U_{N} a group of N𝑁N clients, and by B1,…,BNsubscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑁B_{1},\ldots,B_{N} the private data sets owned by the clients. We consider a classical setting of federated learning [26], where each data set Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} consists of a set of data instances that are independently and identically drawn from an unknown distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. The i𝑖i-th data set Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} is a set of misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} instances.

Definition 2 (Federated Fair Model Training Task).

Given a pair of protected groups {a,b}𝑎𝑏\{a,b\}, a protected class c∈{1,…,C}𝑐1…𝐶c\in\{1,\ldots,C\}, and a threshold ϵ≥0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geq 0 indicating the maximum unfairness that can be tolerated, the federated fair model training task allows a group of clients U1,…,UNsubscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑁U_{1},\ldots,U_{N} to collaborate to train a model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta}, such that

  1. 1.

    The data instances in the private data set of each client, as well as any information about the distribution of the private data set, are not exposed to any other clients or any third party.

  2. 2.

    fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-fair for the instances in the class c𝑐c.

The first requirement is exactly the data privacy-preserving requirement in conventional federated learning [5, 27, 28, 29, 26]. The second requirement is about model fairness, which is not considered by the conventional federated learning tasks.

The above task can be formulated as a constrained optimization problem as follows.

minθ⁡L​(θ)subscript𝜃𝐿𝜃\displaystyle\min_{\theta}L(\theta) (2a)
s.t. ​|La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)|≤ϵ,s.t. superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mbox{s.t. }\left|{L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|\leq\epsilon, (2b)

where L​(θ)=𝔼​[ℓ​(fθ​(𝐱),y)]𝐿𝜃𝔼delimited-[]ℓsubscript𝑓𝜃𝐱𝑦L(\theta)=\mathbb{E}[{\ell(f_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}),y)}] is the expected loss of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} over the unknown distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, and the DGEO constraint in Equation (2b) requires the trained model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} to be ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-fair.

It is difficult to find a solution to Equation (2), because we cannot compute the exact values of L​(θ)𝐿𝜃L(\theta) and La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) without knowing 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. To find a practical solution, we need to accurately estimate the values of L​(θ)𝐿𝜃L(\theta) and La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) while preserving the data privacy of all the clients.

V FedFair: A Practical Solution

In this section, we develop practical solutions to the federated fair model training task. We start with an analysis of the problem. Then, we present a local estimation method. Last, we develop our practical solution.

V-A Problem Analysis

To develop a practical solution to the federated fair model training problem, let us first analyze the opportunities and challenges in estimating L​(θ)𝐿𝜃L(\theta) and La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta).

Similar to [5, 27, 28, 29], we can compute a federated loss that estimates L​(θ)𝐿𝜃L(\theta) by

∑i=1Nmimtotal​L^i​(θ),superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚totalsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝜃\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{m_{i}}{m_{\mbox{total}}}\hat{L}_{i}(\theta), (3)

where mtotal=∑i=1Nmisubscript𝑚totalsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖m_{\mbox{total}}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}m_{i} is the total number of data instances owned by all clients, and L^i​(θ)=1mi​∑(𝐱,s,y)∈Biℓ​(fθ​(𝐱),y)subscript^𝐿𝑖𝜃1subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝐱𝑠𝑦subscript𝐵𝑖ℓsubscript𝑓𝜃𝐱𝑦\hat{L}_{i}(\theta)=\frac{1}{m_{i}}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},s,y)\in B_{i}}\ell(f_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}),y) is the empirical loss of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} on the private data set Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}.

Computing the federated loss does not infringe the data privacy of any client, because each empirical loss L^i​(θ)subscript^𝐿𝑖𝜃\hat{L}_{i}(\theta) is privately computed by the corresponding client Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, and all empirical losses are sent to the cloud server to compute the federated loss.

For every client, the cloud server only knows the empirical loss of the client and the number of instances in the private data set. In other words, the client does not expose any instance or any data distribution information.

The real challenge is to accurately estimate La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) without infringing the data privacy of any client. In the rest of this section, we first introduce a baseline method to estimate La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) and discuss the limitations of this method. Then, we present our federated estimation method to estimate La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) more accurately. Last, we develop an optimization method to find a good solution to the federated fair model training task.

V-B A Local Estimation Approach

To estimate La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) on the unknown distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} while keeping the data privacy of all clients, a baseline method is to let every client Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} use its private data set Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} to compute its local estimation by L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ),superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta), where L^ia,c​(θ)superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta) and L^ib,c​(θ)superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta) are the estimators of the expected conditional losses La,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta) and Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{b,c}(\theta), respectively.

The estimators L^ia,c​(θ)superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta) and L^ib,c​(θ)superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta) are computed on the private data set Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} by L^is,c​(θ)=1mis,c​∑(𝐱,s,c)∈Biℓ​(fθ​(𝐱),c),superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑠𝑐𝜃1superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑠𝑐subscript𝐱𝑠𝑐subscript𝐵𝑖ℓsubscript𝑓𝜃𝐱𝑐\hat{L}_{i}^{s,c}(\theta)=\frac{1}{m_{i}^{s,c}}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},s,c)\in B_{i}}\ell(f_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}),c), where s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\} indicates the group membership of a data instance (𝐱,s,c)𝐱𝑠𝑐(\mathbf{x},s,c), and mis,csuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑠𝑐m_{i}^{s,c} is the number of data instances in Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} that belong to a group s𝑠s and have a class label c𝑐c.

Since all instances in Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} are independently and identically drawn from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, the local estimation is unbiased, that is, 𝔼​(L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ))=La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ).𝔼superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃\mathbb{E}(\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta))=L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta).

We use the local estimations computed on the private data sets of all the clients to build N𝑁N local DGEO constraints as |L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ)|≤ϵ,∀i∈{1,…,N}formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵfor-all𝑖1…𝑁\left|{\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|\leq\epsilon,\forall i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}.

By incorporating these constraints with the federated loss in Equation (3), we convert the problem in Equation (2) into the following locally constrained optimization (LCO) problem.

minθ​∑i=1Nmimtotal​L^i​(θ)subscript𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚totalsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝜃\displaystyle\min_{\theta}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{m_{i}}{m_{\mbox{total}}}\hat{L}_{i}(\theta) (4a)
s.t. ​|L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ)|≤ϵ,∀i∈{1,…,N}formulae-sequences.t. superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵfor-all𝑖1…𝑁\displaystyle\mbox{s.t. }\left|{\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|\leq\epsilon,\forall i\in\{1,\ldots,N\} (4b)

We will show in Section V-D that the LCO problem can be easily solved without infringing the data privacy of any client.

What is the chance that a feasible solution to the LCO problem may achieve a good fairness performance on the distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}? We have the following result.

Theorem 1.

Denote by σi2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\sigma_{i}^{2}, i∈{1,…,N}𝑖1…𝑁i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, the variance of the estimation L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ)superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta), and by σm​i​n2=min⁡(σ12,…,σN2)superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑁2\sigma_{min}^{2}=\min(\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{N}^{2}) the minimum variance. For any feasible solution θ𝜃\theta to the LCO problem and any real number r>0𝑟0r>0, P​(|La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)|<ϵ+r)≥1−σm​i​n2r2𝑃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛2superscript𝑟2P\left(\left|{L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r\right)\geq 1-\frac{\sigma_{min}^{2}}{r^{2}}.

Proof.

Denote by μ​(θ)=La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)𝜇𝜃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃\mu(\theta)=L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta), and by Ri​(θ)=L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ)subscript𝑅𝑖𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃R_{i}(\theta)={\hat{L}}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-{\hat{L}}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta) for a client Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, i∈{1,…,N}𝑖1…𝑁i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}. Here, μ​(θ)𝜇𝜃\mu(\theta) is a random variable because θ𝜃\theta is sampled from the random feasible region defined by Equation (4b).

Since all the data instances in the data set Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} are independently and identically drawn from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, 𝔼​(Ri​(θ))=μ​(θ)𝔼subscript𝑅𝑖𝜃𝜇𝜃\mathbb{E}(R_{i}(\theta))=\mu(\theta) always holds for every sample of θ𝜃\theta.

By substituting 𝔼​(Ri​(θ))=μ​(θ)𝔼subscript𝑅𝑖𝜃𝜇𝜃\mathbb{E}(R_{i}(\theta))=\mu(\theta) into Chebyshev’s inequality, we have P​(|Ri​(θ)−μ​(θ)|<r)≥1−σi2r2𝑃subscript𝑅𝑖𝜃𝜇𝜃𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2superscript𝑟2P\left(\left|{R_{i}(\theta)-\mu(\theta)}\right|<r\right)\geq 1-\frac{\sigma_{i}^{2}}{r^{2}} for every sample of θ𝜃\theta and any real number r>0𝑟0r>0.

Since a feasible solution θ𝜃\theta to the LCO problem always satisfies |Ri​(θ)|≤ϵsubscript𝑅𝑖𝜃italic-ϵ\left|{R_{i}(\theta)}\right|\leq\epsilon, if θ𝜃\theta satisfies |Ri​(θ)−μ​(θ)|<rsubscript𝑅𝑖𝜃𝜇𝜃𝑟\left|{R_{i}(\theta)-\mu(\theta)}\right|<r, then |μ​(θ)|<ϵ+r𝜇𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟\left|{\mu(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r always holds. This further indicates P​(|μ​(θ)|<ϵ+r)≥P​(|Ri​(θ)−μ​(θ)|<r),𝑃𝜇𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟𝑃subscript𝑅𝑖𝜃𝜇𝜃𝑟P\left(\left|{\mu(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r\right)\geq P\left(\left|{R_{i}(\theta)-\mu(\theta)}\right|<r\right), which means P​(|μ​(θ)|<ϵ+r)≥1−σi2r2𝑃𝜇𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2superscript𝑟2P\left(\left|{\mu(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r\right)\geq 1-\frac{\sigma_{i}^{2}}{r^{2}}. Plugging μ​(θ)=La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)𝜇𝜃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃\mu(\theta)=L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) into this inequality, we have P​(|La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)|<ϵ+r)≥1−σi2r2,𝑃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2superscript𝑟2P\left(\left|{L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r\right)\geq 1-\frac{\sigma_{i}^{2}}{r^{2}}, which holds for all the values of i𝑖i in {1,…,N}1…𝑁\{1,\ldots,N\}.

This gives N𝑁N independent inequalities that hold for the clients U1,…,UNsubscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑁U_{1},\ldots,U_{N}, respectively. In all these N𝑁N inequalities, the tightest one is P​(|La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)|<ϵ+r)≥1−σm​i​n2r2,𝑃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛2superscript𝑟2P\left(\left|{L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r\right)\geq 1-\frac{\sigma_{min}^{2}}{r^{2}}, because the other N−1𝑁1N-1 inequalities automatically hold when this inequality holds. The theorem follows. ∎

According to Theorem 1, a solution θ𝜃\theta to the LCO problem will be (ϵ+r)italic-ϵ𝑟(\epsilon+r)-fair with a probability no smaller than a lower bound 1−σm​i​n2r21superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛2superscript𝑟21-\frac{\sigma_{min}^{2}}{r^{2}}. Unfortunately, this lower bound may be small in practice, because the variances σ12,…,σN2superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑁2\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{N}^{2} can be large when the numbers of private data instances owned by clients are not large enough. As a result, solving the LCO problem may have only a small probability to achieve a good model fairness performance.

Moreover, the LCO problem may even be infeasible when a large number of clients introduce a large number of local DGEO constraints, where the intersection of the feasible regions induced by these constraints may have a good chance to be empty due to the large variances σ12,…,σN2superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑁2\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{N}^{2}.

V-C The Federated Estimation Method

Can we compute an unbiased estimation on La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) with a lower variance so that we can achieve a good model fairness performance with a much higher probability?

We can compute an unbiased estimation, named federated estimation, on La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta) by

1N​∑i=1N(L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ))1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)\right) (5)

This estimation is the average of the local estimations computed by all the clients. It is also unbiased, because every local estimation is an unbiased estimation on La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta).

Similar to computing the federated loss, we compute the federated estimation on the cloud server. This does not infringe the data privacy of any client because the local estimations are privately computed by the clients before they are sent to the cloud server.

Next, we analyze the variance of the federated estimation.

Lemma 1.

Denote by σa​v​g2=1N​∑i=1Nσi2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎𝑣𝑔21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\sigma_{avg}^{2}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\sigma_{i}^{2} the average of the variances σ12,…,σN2superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑁2\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{N}^{2}. Then, the variance σf​e​d2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑓𝑒𝑑2\sigma_{fed}^{2} of the federated estimation is σa​v​g2Nsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎𝑣𝑔2𝑁\frac{\sigma_{avg}^{2}}{N}.

Proof.

Since the private data sets B1,…,BNsubscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑁B_{1},\ldots,B_{N} are independently and identically drawn from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, the local estimations computed on these private data sets are independent from each other. Therefore, we can derive

σf​e​d2=𝕍​[1N​∑i=1N(L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ))]=σa​v​g2Nsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑓𝑒𝑑2𝕍delimited-[]1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎𝑣𝑔2𝑁\displaystyle\sigma_{fed}^{2}=\mathbb{V}\left[{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left({\hat{L}}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-{\hat{L}}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)\right)}\right]=\frac{\sigma_{avg}^{2}}{N}

∎

According to Lemma 1, σf​e​d2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑓𝑒𝑑2\sigma_{fed}^{2} monotonically decreases when the number of clients increases. In other words, the federated estimation becomes more accurate when more clients join the federation.

We use the federated estimation to develop a federated DGEO constraint as |1N​∑i=1N(L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ))|≤ϵ,1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ\left|{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)\right)}\right|\leq\epsilon, and further incorporate this constraint with the federated loss in Equation (3) to convert the constrained optimization problem in Equation (2) into the following FedFair problem.

minθ​∑i=1Nmimtotal​L^i​(θ)subscript𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚totalsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝜃\displaystyle\min_{\theta}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{m_{i}}{m_{\mbox{total}}}\hat{L}_{i}(\theta) (6a)
s.t. ​|1N​∑i=1N(L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ))|≤ϵs.t. 1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mbox{s.t. }\left|{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)\right)}\right|\leq\epsilon (6b)

The following theorem analyzes the model fairness performance of a solution to the FedFair problem.

Theorem 2.

For any feasible solution θ𝜃\theta to the FedFair problem and any r>0𝑟0r>0, P​(|La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)|<ϵ+r)≥1−σa​v​g2N​r2𝑃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎𝑣𝑔2𝑁superscript𝑟2P\left(\left|{L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r\right)\geq 1-\frac{\sigma_{avg}^{2}}{Nr^{2}}.

Proof.

Following the proof of Theorem 1 and Chebyshev’s inequality, P​(|La,c​(θ)−Lb,c​(θ)|<ϵ+r)≥1−σf​e​d2r2𝑃superscript𝐿𝑎𝑐𝜃superscript𝐿𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑓𝑒𝑑2superscript𝑟2P\left(\left|{L^{a,c}(\theta)-L^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|<\epsilon+r\right)\geq 1-\frac{\sigma_{fed}^{2}}{r^{2}} holds for any r>0𝑟0r>0. By Lemma 1, the theorem follows. ∎

To compare the model fairness performance of the FedFair approach and the LCO approach using Theorems 1 and 2, we have to analyze the difference between σa​v​g2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎𝑣𝑔2\sigma_{avg}^{2} and σm​i​n2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛2\sigma_{min}^{2}, which depends on the differences among σ12,…,σN2superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑁2\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{N}^{2}. Since we use the same formula to compute every local estimation based on the data instances drawn from the same distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, the differences among σ12,…,σN2superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑁2\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{N}^{2} are determined by the differences among the numbers of data instances owned by different clients.

In typical federated learning applications [5, 27, 26], clients often have similar amounts of data. This produces small differences among σ12,…,σN2superscriptsubscript𝜎12…superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑁2\sigma_{1}^{2},\ldots,\sigma_{N}^{2}, which further means σa​v​g2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎𝑣𝑔2\sigma_{avg}^{2} and σm​i​n2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛2\sigma_{min}^{2} are close to each other. Because of the factor of N𝑁N in Lemma 1, the variance σf​e​d2=σa​v​g2Nsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑓𝑒𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎𝑣𝑔2𝑁\sigma_{fed}^{2}=\frac{\sigma_{avg}^{2}}{N} of the federated estimation is much smaller than the minimum variance σm​i​n2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛2\sigma_{min}^{2} of the local estimations. In consequence, based on Theorems 1 and 2, a solution to the FedFair problem can have a much higher probability to achieve good model fairness performance than a solution to the LCO problem.

V-D Solving the FedFair and LCO Problems

In this subsection, we discuss how to solve the FedFair problem and the LCO problem without infringing the data privacy of any client. We first convert the FedFair problem to a nonconvex-concave min-max problem. Then, we apply the alternating gradient projection (AGP) algorithm [4] to tackle the min-max problem without infringing the data privacy of any client. We also extend AGP to tackle the LCO problem in a similar privacy-preserving way.

AGP [4] is designed to obtain a δ𝛿\delta-stationary point of a nonconvex-concave minmax problem in 𝒪​(δ−4)𝒪superscript𝛿4\mathcal{O}(\delta^{-4}) iterations. It alternatively updates primal and dual variables by employing simple projected gradient steps at each iteration.

Denote by D^i​(θ)=L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ),i∈{1,…,N}formulae-sequencesubscript^𝐷𝑖𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃𝑖1…𝑁\hat{D}_{i}(\theta)=\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta),i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, the local estimation of the client Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}. We rewrite the federated DGEO constraint in the FedFair problem to

−ϵ≤1N​∑i=1ND^i​(θ)≤ϵ,italic-ϵ1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript^𝐷𝑖𝜃italic-ϵ\displaystyle-\epsilon\leq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\hat{D}_{i}(\theta)\leq\epsilon, (7)

which represents two constraints on θ𝜃\theta.

In this way, the FedFair problem can be equivalently converted to a min-max problem

minθ⁡maxλa,λb≥0⁡ℒ​(θ,λa,λb),subscript𝜃subscriptsubscript𝜆𝑎subscript𝜆𝑏0ℒ𝜃subscript𝜆𝑎subscript𝜆𝑏\min_{\theta}\max_{\lambda_{a},\lambda_{b}\geq 0}{\mathcal{L}}(\theta,\lambda_{a},\lambda_{b}), (8)

where

ℒ​(θ,λa,λb)=ℒ𝜃subscript𝜆𝑎subscript𝜆𝑏absent\displaystyle{\mathcal{L}}(\theta,\lambda_{a},\lambda_{b})= ∑i=1Nmimtotal​L^i​(θ)+λa​(1N​∑i=1ND^i​(θ)−ϵ)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚totalsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝜃subscript𝜆𝑎1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript^𝐷𝑖𝜃italic-ϵ\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{m_{i}}{m_{\mbox{total}}}\hat{L}_{i}(\theta)+\lambda_{a}\left(\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\hat{D}_{i}(\theta)-\epsilon\right)
−λb​(1N​∑i=1ND^i​(θ)+ϵ),subscript𝜆𝑏1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript^𝐷𝑖𝜃italic-ϵ\displaystyle-\lambda_{b}\left(\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\hat{D}_{i}(\theta)+\epsilon\right),

is a Lagrangian function with the Lagrange multipliers λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λbsubscript𝜆𝑏\lambda_{b} introduced for the two constraints in Equation (7), respectively.

The Lagrangian function is nonconvex in terms of θ𝜃\theta and concave in terms of λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λbsubscript𝜆𝑏\lambda_{b}. Thus, the problem in Equation (8) is a nonconvex-convave min-max problem that can be directly solved using the AGP [4].

Each iteration of AGP updates θ𝜃\theta, λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λbsubscript𝜆𝑏\lambda_{b} using the gradients computed from a regularized loss function

ℒ¯​(θ,λa,λb)=ℒ​(θ,λa,λb)−γ2​(λa2+λb2),¯ℒ𝜃subscript𝜆𝑎subscript𝜆𝑏ℒ𝜃subscript𝜆𝑎subscript𝜆𝑏𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑏2\bar{\mathcal{L}}(\theta,\lambda_{a},\lambda_{b})={\mathcal{L}}(\theta,\lambda_{a},\lambda_{b})-\frac{\gamma}{2}(\lambda_{a}^{2}+\lambda_{b}^{2}), (9)

where γ2​(λa2+λb2)𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑏2\frac{\gamma}{2}(\lambda_{a}^{2}+\lambda_{b}^{2}) is a regularization term that makes ℒ¯​(θ,λa,λb)¯ℒ𝜃subscript𝜆𝑎subscript𝜆𝑏\bar{\mathcal{L}}(\theta,\lambda_{a},\lambda_{b}) strongly concave with respect to λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λbsubscript𝜆𝑏\lambda_{b} to achieve a faster convergence speed, and γ≥0𝛾0\gamma\geq 0 is a small hyper-parameter to control the level of regularization.

Specifically, the k𝑘k-th iteration of AGP consists of one gradient step to update θ𝜃\theta and one projected gradient descent step to update λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λbsubscript𝜆𝑏\lambda_{b}.

The first step updates θ𝜃\theta with a step size α𝛼\alpha by

θk+1=θk−α​∑i=1N∇i(θk),superscript𝜃𝑘1superscript𝜃𝑘𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript∇𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k+1}=\theta^{k}-{\alpha}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla_{i}(\theta^{k}), (10)

where

∇i(θk)=mimtotal​∇L^i​(θk)+λak−λbkN​∇D^i​(θk)subscript∇𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚total∇subscript^𝐿𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑎𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑏𝑘𝑁∇subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\nabla_{i}(\theta^{k})=\frac{m_{i}}{m_{\mbox{total}}}\nabla\hat{L}_{i}({\theta^{k}})+\frac{\lambda_{a}^{k}-\lambda_{b}^{k}}{N}\nabla\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}}) (11)

is the gradient computed by the client Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}. Here, ∇L^i​(θk)∇subscript^𝐿𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\nabla\hat{L}_{i}({\theta^{k}}) and ∇D^i​(θk)∇subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\nabla\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}}) are respectively the gradients of L^i​(θk)subscript^𝐿𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\hat{L}_{i}(\theta^{k}) and D^i​(θk)subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}}) with respect to θksuperscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k}. These gradients are computed by the client Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} using Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}.

The second step updates λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λbsubscript𝜆𝑏\lambda_{b} with the a step size β𝛽\beta by

λak+1=max⁡((1−γ​β)​λak+βN​∑i=1ND^i​(θk)−β​ϵ,0)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑎𝑘11𝛾𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑎𝑘𝛽𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘𝛽italic-ϵ0\lambda_{a}^{k+1}=\max\left({(1-\gamma\beta)\lambda_{a}^{k}+\frac{\beta}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}})-\beta\epsilon},0\right) (12)

and

λbk+1=max⁡((1−γ​β)​λbk−βN​∑iND^i​(θk)−β​ϵ,0).superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑏𝑘11𝛾𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑏𝑘𝛽𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑁subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘𝛽italic-ϵ0\lambda_{b}^{k+1}=\max\left({(1-\gamma\beta)\lambda_{b}^{k}-\frac{\beta}{N}\sum_{i}^{N}\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}})-\beta\epsilon},0\right). (13)

The above iteration continues until AGP converges. Algorithm 1 shows how we deploy AGP in a federated learning framework to tackle the FedFair problem.

The LCO problem can be solved in a similar way as the FedFair problem by using AGP [4].

First, we introduce a pair of Lagrange multipliers, denoted by λaisubscript𝜆subscript𝑎𝑖\lambda_{a_{i}} and λbisubscript𝜆subscript𝑏𝑖\lambda_{b_{i}}, i∈{1,…,N}𝑖1…𝑁i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, for each local DGEO constraint rewritten as −ϵ≤L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ)≤ϵitalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ-\epsilon\leq\hat{L}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-\hat{L}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)\leq\epsilon.

Then, we can adapt Algorithm 1 by replacing Equation (11) by ∇i(θk)=mimtotal​∇L^i​(θk)+(λaik−λbik)​∇D^i​(θk),subscript∇𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚total∇subscript^𝐿𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆subscript𝑎𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆subscript𝑏𝑖𝑘∇subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\nabla_{i}(\theta^{k})=\frac{m_{i}}{m_{\mbox{total}}}\nabla\hat{L}_{i}({\theta^{k}})+(\lambda_{a_{i}}^{k}-\lambda_{b_{i}}^{k})\nabla\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}}), and replacing Equations (12) and (13), respectively, by λaik+1=max⁡((1−γ​β)​λaik+β​D^i​(θk)−β​ϵ,0)superscriptsubscript𝜆subscript𝑎𝑖𝑘11𝛾𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜆subscript𝑎𝑖𝑘𝛽subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘𝛽italic-ϵ0\lambda_{a_{i}}^{k+1}=\max\left({(1-\gamma\beta)\lambda_{a_{i}}^{k}+{\beta}\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}})-\beta\epsilon},0\right) and λbik+1=max⁡((1−γ​β)​λbik−β​D^i​(θk)−β​ϵ,0).superscriptsubscript𝜆subscript𝑏𝑖𝑘11𝛾𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜆subscript𝑏𝑖𝑘𝛽subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘𝛽italic-ϵ0\lambda_{b_{i}}^{k+1}=\max\left({(1-\gamma\beta)\lambda_{b_{i}}^{k}-{\beta}\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}})-\beta\epsilon},0\right).

Since both Algorithm 1 and its extension for the LCO problem implement the AGP algorithm, they have the same convergence behaviour as AGP [4]. The hyper-parameters are set as α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05, β=0.05𝛽0.05\beta=0.05 and γ=0.001𝛾0.001\gamma=0.001. To prevent divergence in training, we reduce the value of α𝛼\alpha by α←0.1×α←𝛼0.1𝛼\alpha\leftarrow 0.1\times\alpha per 20,0002000020,000 gradient descend steps.

Does Algorithm 1 protect the privacy of the private data owned by each client? Yes, it protects the data privacy of the clients in a similar way as [5, 29, 46]. Because, in each iteration, there is no communication between the clients, and the information sent from a client to the cloud server only contains D^i​(θk)subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\hat{D}_{i}(\theta^{k}), ∇D^i​(θk)∇subscript^𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\nabla\hat{D}_{i}({\theta^{k}}) and ∇L^i​(θk)∇subscript^𝐿𝑖superscript𝜃𝑘\nabla\hat{L}_{i}({\theta^{k}}), which do not expose the private data sets of clients or any information about the distribution of the private datasets.

VI Experimental Results

In this section, we conduct a series of experiments to evaluate the performance of our proposed methods for federated fair model training, and compare with the state-of-the-art baselines. We first describe the experiment settings and then present the experimental results.

VI-A Experiment Settings

In our experiments, we evaluate the performance of a series of seven methods. First of all, FedFair is our proposed method solving the FedFair Problem in Equation (6). Second, LCO is the method solving the LCO problem in Equation (4). Third, we use the state-of-the-art federated fair model training method AgnosticFair (AF) [3] as a baseline.

As the fourth and the fifth methods in our experiments, we compare with a separate training (ST) method and the classical federated learning method FedAvg [5]. We also extend FedAvg by two post-processing fairness enhancing methods, equalized odds (EO) [15] and calibrated equalized odds (CEO) [22], to obtain the sixth and the seventh methods in our experiments.

The ST method simply asks each client Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} to use its own private training data set Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} to train a fair model by solving the following constrained optimization problem.

minθ⁡L^i​(θ)subscript𝜃subscript^𝐿𝑖𝜃\displaystyle\min_{\theta}{\hat{L}}_{i}(\theta) (14a)
s.t. ​|L^ia,c​(θ)−L^ib,c​(θ)|≤ϵs.t. superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑎𝑐𝜃superscriptsubscript^𝐿𝑖𝑏𝑐𝜃italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mbox{s.t. }\left|{{\hat{L}}_{i}^{a,c}(\theta)-{\hat{L}}_{i}^{b,c}(\theta)}\right|\leq\epsilon (14b)

The post-processing methods, such as EO and CEO, are used to separately post-process the model trained by FedAvg for each client based on its private training data set. This will produce N𝑁N fairness enhanced models for N𝑁N clients. We report the average performance and the variance of those N𝑁N models.

For all the methods except AF, we use two types of models for fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta}. One is logistic regression, the other one is a fully connected neural network with two hidden layers, where the first and the second hidden layers contain eight and four ReLU units, respectively.

We do not report the performance of AF for the neural network model because the source code of AF is not applicable to training neural networks.

The source codes of all the baseline methods are provided by the authors of [3, 5, 15, 22]. FedFair and LCO are implemented in PyTorch 1.4, the source code is available at: https://bit.ly/fedfair. All the experiments are conducted on Dell Alienware with Intel(R) Core(TM) i9-9980XE CPU, 128G memory, NVIDIA 1080Ti, and Ubuntu 16.04.

VI-B Data Sets

We adopt the following three benchmark data sets that have been widely used in literature to evaluate the performances of fair model training methods [47, 25].

The ADULT data set [48] contains 45,222 data instances. Each data instance consists of 14 features of a person. The binary class label of a data instance indicates whether a person’s annual income is above 50,0005000050,000 dollars or not. Following the settings of Hardt et al. [15], we use ‘female’ and ‘male’ as the pair of protected groups, and use “above 50,0005000050,000 dollars” as the protected class. We uniformly sample 40,000 data instances as the training data, and use the remaining 5,222 data instances as the testing data. The training data is uniformly partitioned into 50 private training data sets, each owned by a client.

The COMPAS data set [49] contains 5,278 data instances. Every data instance consists of 16 features of a person. The binary class label of a data instance indicates whether the person is a recidivist or not. Following the settings of Hardt et al. [15], we use ‘African-American’ and ‘Caucasian’ as the pair of protected groups, and use “not a recidivist” as the protected class. We uniformly sample 4,800 data instances as the training data, and use the remaining 478 data instances as the testing data. The training data is uniformly partitioned into 20 private training data sets, each owned by a client.

The DRUG data set [50] contains 1,885 data instances. Each data instance represents a person characterized by 12 features. The binary class label of a data instance indicates whether the person abuses volatile substance or not. We use ‘white’ and ‘non-white’ as the pair of protected groups, and use “not abuse volatile substance” as the protected class. We uniformly sample 1,600 data instances for training, and use the remaining 285 data instances for testing. The training data is uniformly partitioned into 10 private training data sets, each owned by a client.

For all the data sets, every categorical feature is converted into a set of binary features using one-hot encoding111https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-hot.

The private training data sets owned by the clients are used to train models. The testing data sets are used to evaluate the prediction accuracies and the fairness of the models produced by all the methods.

VI-C Fairness Measurement

In our experiments, the fairness of a trained model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is evaluated by fairness=1−DEO​(fθ),fairness1DEOsubscript𝑓𝜃\text{fairness}=1-\text{DEO}(f_{\theta}), where DEO​(fθ)DEOsubscript𝑓𝜃\text{DEO}(f_{\theta}) [25] is extended from the notion of equal opportunity [15] to measure how unfair a model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is. According to Donini et al. [25], a small DGEO usually indicates a small DEO(fθ)subscript𝑓𝜃(f_{\theta}), which means good fairness. The range of fairness is between 00 and 111. A larger value of fairness means the model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is fairer.

We also evaluate the overall performance of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} by the harmonic mean of its fairness and accuracy, which is simply referred to as harmonic mean when the context is clear.

For ST, EO and CEO that produce N𝑁N different models for N𝑁N clients, respectively, we report the average accuracy, the average fairness and the average of the harmonic means of the N𝑁N models on the testing data sets.

VI-D Fairness and Accuracy of Trained Models

For each of ST, LCO, AF and FedFair, we conduct a grid search on the hyper parameter that controls the trade-off between fairness and accuracy. This produces multiple trained models for every method, where each model is trained using a unique value of the hyper parameter. For every method, we report the performance of the models that achieve the top-5 largest harmonic means.

The fairness and the accuracy of each of the top-5 models is plotted as a point in Figure 1. Some methods show less than five points in a figure because some points may overlap with each other.

FedAvg, EO and CEO do not provide a hyper parameter to control the trade-off between fairness and accuracy, thus we can only use their default settings to run each of them once on every data set. As a result, there is only one point for each of FedAvg, EO and CEO in every figure of Figure 1.

As it is shown in Figure 1, the models trained by ST do not perform well in either fairness or accuracy due to the lack of collaboration among clients during training. The model trained by FedAvg cannot achieve a good fairness due to the ignorance of fairness during training. The models post-processed by EO and CEO cannot achieve a good fairness and a good accuracy at the same time, because the improvements on their fairness are usually gained at the cost of sacrificing accuracy [1].

The in-processing methods, such as LCO, AF and FedFair, achieve better results, because they can explicitly impose the required trade-off between accuracy and fairness in the objective functions to find a good balance during training [19].

The accuracies of the models trained by LCO, AF and FedFair are mostly comparable, but FedFair always achieves the best fairness performance. This demonstrates the outstanding performance of FedFair in training fair models with high accuracies.

The accuracies of the logistic regression models in Figure 1(a) are slightly better than the accuracies of the corresponding neural network models in Figure 1(b) because the neural network models tend to overfit the small training data of DRUG.

We can also conclude from Figure 1 that the fairness of the models trained by LCO is weaker than that of FedFair on most of the data sets, because the LCO problem quickly becomes infeasible when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon gets small, which makes it impossible to improve the fairness of the models trained by LCO.

To the contrary, the FedFair problem stays feasible for small values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, thus it is able to train models with a much higher fairness than LCO with only slight overhead in accuracy.

Tables I and II summarize the performance of all the compared methods. To analyze the variance of the performance, we repeat the random data set construction process introduced in Section VI-B to construct four additional data sets for each of DRUG, COMPASS and ADULT. Every additional data set is randomly constructed by using a unique random seed to generate the N𝑁N private training data sets and the testing data set. Including the first data set we constructed at the beginning, in total we have a collection of five random data sets for each of DRUG, COMPASS and ADULT.

For FedAvg, AF, LCO and FedFair, we train five models on the five random data sets in the same collection. Then, we evaluate the mean and standard deviation of the accuracies, fairness and harmonic means of the five models. For EO, CEO and ST, we train one model per client on each of the five random data sets in the same collection. This produces 5​N5𝑁5N models for each collection of random data sets, where N𝑁N is the number of clients. Then, we evaluate the mean and standard deviation of the accuracies, fairness and harmonic means of the 5​N5𝑁5N models. For ST, AF, LCO and FedFair, we use the optimal hyper parameter that achieves the best harmonic mean performance. FedAvg, EO and CEO are evaluated with default settings because they do not provide a hyper parameter to control the trade-off between accuracy and fairness.

As shown in Tables I and II, in most cases, the accuracies of the models trained by FedFair are comparable with the other methods, but FedFair achieves the best fairness most of the cases, and always achieves the best harmonic mean. This demonstrates the outstanding performance of FedFair in training fair models with high accuracies.

VI-E Effect of Parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon

We first analyze how ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon affects the fairness and accuracy of the logistic regression models trained by FedFair. As shown in Figure 2, for each data set, we use FedFair to train a logistic regression model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} with every value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and report the performance of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta}, including the absolute value of the federated estimation (see Equation (5)) on the training data, the DGEO on the testing data, fairness, and accuracy. Please note that the absolute value of the federated estimation (AFE for short in this section) is the lefthand side of the federated DGEO constraint in Equation (6b).

In Figures 2(a), 2(c) and 2(e), AFE (the solid line) is always not larger than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. When ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is small, AFE reaches the value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. In other words, the federated DGEO constraint is activated to constrain model fairness during training. When ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is large, AFE is substantially lower than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and FedFair can satisfy the fairness requirement without sacrificing accuracy.

In Figures 2(a), 2(c) and 2(e), the DGEO curve (the dashed line) on the testing data closely follows the trend of the corresponding AFE curve. This shows that the federated DGEO constraint applied on the training data generalizes well in constraining the DGEO on the testing data, which makes FedFair highly effective in training fair models.

Figures 2(b), 2(d) and 2(f) show how ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon affects the accuracy and the fairness of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta}. On all the data sets, the accuracy of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} drops when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon becomes smaller, because reducing ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon induces a tighter federated DGEO constraint, shrinks the feasible region of the FedFair problem, and makes it harder to find a good solution. Figures 2(b) and 2(d) show that reducing ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon significantly improves the fairness of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta}, since a smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon requires fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} to have a smaller DGEO, that is, to be fairer.

However, a smaller DGEO does not always induce a higher fairness. The reason is that fairness is defined based on the notion of DEO(fθ)subscript𝑓𝜃(f_{\theta}), which is equivalent to DGEO only if a hard loss function ℓ​(fθ​(𝐱),y)=𝟙y∗fθ​(𝐱)≤0ℓsubscript𝑓𝜃𝐱𝑦subscript1𝑦subscript𝑓𝜃𝐱0\ell(f_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}),y)=\mathds{1}_{y*f_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})\leq 0} is used [25]. The hard loss function cannot be used to train the logistic regression model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta}, thus DGEO is not equivalent to DEO(fθ)subscript𝑓𝜃(f_{\theta}) in our case. As a result, when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon gets smaller than 0.10, the DGEO in Figure 2(e) decreases, but the corresponding fairness in Figure 2(f) drops as well. However, this does not affect the practical performance of FedFair much. As discussed in Section VI-D, FedFair always achieves the best performance on all data sets.

Next, we analyze the effect of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon on the performance of the neural network models trained by FedFair in Figure 3, where the curves are drawn in the same way as Figure 2.

In Figures 3(c) and 3(e), the DGEO represented by the dashed curves are closely following the trends of the corresponding solid curves of absolute federated estimations (AFE). This demonstrates that the federated DGEO constraint applied on the training data generalizes well in constraining the DGEO on the testing data, which further means FedFair is highly effective in training fair neural network models.

However, the federated DGEO constraint may not generalize well when the training data set is too small. As shown in Figure 3(a), the DGEO curve on the small DRUG data set first drops with the decrease of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, but then becomes large again when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon becomes smaller than 0.075. This is because a small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon forces the neural network model to overfit the federated DGEO constraint on the small training data set of DRUG, which reduces the effectiveness of the constraint in controlling the DGEO on the testing data.

The logistic regression model in Figure 2(a) does not overfit the federated constraint on the training data set of DRUG because it has a much lower model complexity than the neural network model.

Now, let’s discuss the accuracy and fairness performances in Figures 3(b), 3(d) and 3(f). Different from the accuracies of the logistic regression models in Figures 2(b),  2(d) and  2(f), the accuracies of the neural network models do not always drop with the decrease of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. This is largely due to the high model complexity and high non-linearity of the neural network models, where a tighter federated DGEO constraint induced by a smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon may act as a regularization term to improve the testing accuracies of the neural network models.

We can also observe in Figure 3 that a smaller DGEO does not always induce a larger fairness for the neural network models. This is because the notion of DEO(fθ)subscript𝑓𝜃(f_{\theta}), from which we develop fairness, is not equivalent to DGEO when we use cross-entropy loss to train neural network models [25].

However, this does not affect the practical performance of FedFair very much. As demonstrated in Subsection VI-D, the neural network models trained by FedFair always achieve the best harmonic mean performance.

VII Influence of Dropping Clients

Following the standard experiments of classical federated learning methods [5, 27, 28, 29, 26], we randomly drop a proportion of clients offline in each iteration of the training processes of FedFair and LCO, and evaluate how dropping clients affects the harmonic mean of a trained model. For each of LCO and FedFair, we report the best performance in Figure 4 using the optimal value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon that corresponds to the model with the largest harmonic mean. The performances of the other methods are always inferior to FedFair, thus we skip the discussions on them due to limit of space.

The proportion of dropped clients is called drop rate. Figure 4 shows the harmonic means of FedFair and LCO for the drop rates of 0.0,0.1,0.30.00.10.30.0,0.1,0.3 and 0.5. Here, a drop rate 0.0 means no client is dropped.

In most cases, the harmonic mean of the model trained by LCO decreases when the drop rate increases from 0.0 to 0.1. Because dropping a client drops the corresponding local DGEO constraint of the LCO problem, and the fairness of the model trained by LCO will be reduced if some dominating active local DGEO constraints are dropped during training.

The harmonic mean of the model trained by LCO stays stable for the drop rates 0.1, 0.3 and 0.5, which means dropping more local DGEO constraints does not affect the performance of the model if the dominating active constraints are already dropped.

Comparing to LCO, FedFair achieves a much better robustness to dropping clients. As shown in Figures 4(a), 4(c) and 4(e), the harmonic means of the logistic regression models trained by FedFair stay unchanged at very high values for all the drop rates. This outstanding robustness of FedFair to dropping clients is inherited from the robustness of the federated estimation, because the federated estimation is the average of the local estimations, which is very robust to dropped clients.

When training neural network models, the robustness of FedFair to dropping clients is a little bit different from training linear models. In Figures 4(b) and 4(d), on the small data sets of DRUG and COMPASS, the harmonic mean of the neural network model trained by FedFair decreases when the drop rate increases. Because training neural network models requires a lot of data, but dropping clients reduces the amount of available private data sets, which limits the collaboration effectiveness among clients. However, FedFair is still very robust to dropping clients on the large ADULT data set. As shown in Figure 4(f), dropping clients does not affect the harmonic means of the neural network models trained by FedFair.

In summary, FedFair is highly robust to dropping clients, and the models trained by FedFair achieve the best harmonic mean performance on all the data sets.

VIII Conclusions

In this paper, we tackle the novel task of training fair models in cross-silo federated learning. We first propose an effective federated estimation method to accurately estimate the fairness of a model, and we also analyze why it achieves a smaller estimation variance than locally estimating the fairness of a model on every client. Based on the federated estimation, we develop a fairness constraint that can be smoothly incorporated into an effective federated learning framework to train high-performance fair models without infringing the data privacy of any client.
